result.notes: 30 units ordered (24 new build + 6 conversions) per Spielberger. However, only prototype definitively confirmed through factory photographs. No documentation confirms order completion or delivery. No combat records or capture evidence exists.
653 units produced by multiple manufacturers (Daimler-Benz, MAN, Alkett, Henschel, Wegmann, MNH, MIAG). Chassis numbers 74101-75500. Multiple authoritative sources consistently confirm dates.

175 units with long 7.5cm KwK 40 L/43 gun. F2 designation officially adopted March 21, 1942. Redesignated as Ausf. G on June 5, 1942 (finalized July 1, 1942) to avoid confusion with short-gunned Ausf. F. Transitional designation.

PROTOTYPE ONLY - NO SERIES PRODUCTION. Two Schmalturm turrets completed (Aug 1944, Jan 1945), ~8 hulls and 3 turrets in various stages by April 1945. Mass production scheduled for March-April 1945 but war ended before it began. NOT a production vehicle.

18 vehicles converted from Tiger I chassis by Alkett. Production breakdown: 3 in August, 10 in September, 5 in December 1944. Prototype completed October 1943, but series production began August 1944.

Conversion program: Alkett converted 200 captured French Renault R35 tanks (174 tank destroyers + 26 command vehicles). Prototype Feb 1941, approved by Hitler Mar 31, 1941. First units deployed for Operation Barbarossa June 1941.

24 Hotchkiss H39 tanks converted by Baukommando Becker at Hotchkiss plant in Paris. Conversions followed Lorraine-based Marder I production (July-August 1942), suggesting late summer to end of 1942 timeframe. No exact month-level precision available.

170 vehicles (Sd.Kfz 135 Marder I). Converted by Baukommando Becker using captured French Lorraine 37L chassis. Production split: 104 units in July, 66 units in August. Official adoption June 9, 1942 to completion by end August 1942.

48 units converted from captured French Hotchkiss H39 chassis by Baukommando Becker at Hotchkiss factory near Paris. Hitler authorized expanded conversions after May 23, 1942 demonstration. Lorraine conversions July-August 1942; Hotchkiss conversions likely mid-late 1942.

8 vehicles converted from captured French FCM 36 tanks by Alfred Becker's Baukommando in fall 1942 (per Jentz & Doyle's Panzer Tracts). Conflicting sources suggest higher numbers (24 or 48) in 1943/44, but these are less reliable. Withdrawn by early 1944 due to parts shortages.
